moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Nc3 Nf6: Playing with the idea in mind that this might transpose into the open Sicilian with d4.
moves.4. Bc4 e6 5. O-O Be7 6. d3: Transposing into a closed Sicilian black usually prefers to have his bishop posted on the long h8 a1 diagonal, but due to the move order the bishop is on a less desirable square.
moves.6... a6: This move is common for the Sicilian taking the b5 square from the white pieces it also prepares the push b5.
moves.7. Bg5 Nc6 8. a3: Not sure if this was a waiting move or if white wanted to prevent Nb4 which I wasn't going to play my knight is more important right now defending e5.  Another possibility was this was to prepare b4 but I don't find that a good plan and I stopped it.
moves.8... b5: Natural continuation the bishop doesn't look good on d7 to me.  I'd much rather have it slicing into whites king side on b7.
moves.9. Bb3 O-O 10. Ne2: Gives up the control of the d5 square so I take it.
moves.14... Ne7: I defend the square and prepare to bring my knight to f5 or d5 at a later date.
moves.15... d4: ! a positional move isolating the d3 pawn and making the last move look inferior.
moves.16. cxd4 Bxd4: This seems like a strange move giving up the bishop pair however I felt that a pawn on d4 is not as effective as my Queen on d4 so I gave up the bishop pair for a structural advantage which is usually the long term advantage of the bishop pair anyway.
moves.17. Nxd4 Qxd4 18. Qc1: defenses both threats of Qxf4 and Qxb2.
moves.18... Nd5: Attacking the knight on f4 and centralizing my knight.
moves.19... Qxd5 20. f3: blocking the threat of Qxg2 but puts another pawn on the same color as the c2 bishop.
moves.21. Qf4 Re2: The rooks best rank ! the black pieces are dominate in this position.
moves.22. Rac1 Rae8 23. Qg3: ? allows black the opportunity to come into the position.
moves.23... Qd4+ 24. Kh1 Qxb2 25. Rfe1: And everything looks safe however this is not true.  Black has the winning tactic Qxc2! which I saw when I played Qd4+ coming into b2.  The only move white had was Bb1 and white looks really passive not to mention 2 pawns down.  However this is much worse.
moves.25... Qxc2: !! Rxc2 Rxe1+ Qxe1 Rxe1# game over.  Rxe2 Qxc1+! Q(R)e1 Qxe1+ R(Q)xe1 Rxe1#.  Notice that both my rook and queen are totally protected form capture.
moves.26. h3: !? White releases the tension on his back rank.
moves.27. Rxe1 Rxe1+: ? Bc6 was better due to problems with the b7 bishop.
moves.28. Qxe1: I'm not out of the woods yet white has a chance to attempt to get my Bishop on b7.  Which it looks like he could have done but he missed the chance to get back into this game.
moves.28... Kf8: defending myself from back rank mates.
moves.29. Qe3: ? the move here was Qe5! which would end up making the loss of my b7 bishop unavoidable.  However I believe after Qe5 black is still winning but white would have some drawing opportunities.
moves.29... Qc3: ? Trying to get my queen back into the protection of my king however my bishop is still lost after Qf4.  I should have played Bd5 moving to e6 should white threaten to take it.  White however doesn't see his chances and resigns here.  It would have been a hard fought endgame for me to go on and win after loosing my bishop.  I believe black is still winning but you have to give a fight when the game is still very close being up a few pawns is still hard to win in a queen endgame, especially with my exposed king.
